front.head: This cast list has been adapted from the 1679 folio edition of Beaumont and Fletcher's Fifty Comedies and Tragedies. Spelling has been regularized based on how names appear in the dialogue, and new descriptions have been supplied.

div.stage: Enter Raymond, Sebastian, Nicusa, and Sailors.

lg.l: Here's nothing, sir, but poverty and hunger;
No promise of inhabitance, neither tract tract: path travelled by person or animal of beast
Nor foot of man. We have searched
All this rocky desert yet cannot discover any assurance
Here is or hath been such men.
Not a relic of anything they wore
Nor mark left by 'em either to find relief
Or to warn others from the like misfortune.
Believe it, these fellows are both false false: deceitful,
And to get a little succor succor: help, aid, or assistance in their misery
Have framed this cunning tale.
The ship, I know, is French, and owned by pirates,
If not by Albert, my arch enemy.
You told me too there was a woman with 'em,
A young and handsome woman.
There was so, sir.

And such and such young gallants gallants: Using the term "gallants" to describe the men that Sebastian and Nicusa reported being on the island is significant because it indicates Raymond's class expectations. "Gallants" is a term that describes young men as "smartly" or" finely-dressed" who are "gorgeous or showy in appearance." In a way, Raymond is reminding Sebastian and Nicusa that they had described a group of men on the island who were well-dressed, which would mean they are of the higher or wealthier class. Ironically, "gallants" is a term that is very much the opposite of what one would expect to find on the barren island where, as the audience knows by this point, there is no chance of prosperity. Because these men are so contrasting to what the island looks like and could support, it stands to reason that it should also be doubly easy to find them..
We told ye true, sir,
That they had no means to quitquit: leave, escape this island—
And that amidst their mutiny to save your lives
You got their ship.
All is most certain, sir.
Where are they, then? Where are these men
Or woman? We are landed where your faiths
Did assure us we could not miss their sights;
For this news we took ye to our mercy,
Relieved ye when the furious sea and famine
Strove which should first devour ye,
Clothed and cherished ye, used ye as those ye say ye are.
Fair gentlemen, now keep your words
And show us this company your own free pities spoke of;
These men ye left in misery, the woman.
Men of those noble breedings you pretend topretend to: allege
Should scornscorn: hold in disdain to lie or get their food with falsehood.
Come, direct us.
Alas, sir, they are gone,

But by what means or providence providence: divine guidance. The term marks another instance where a word's non-religious and religious definitions can both function simultaneously. Sebastian could be stating that he does not know what foresight and/or supplies may have allowed the Frenchmen to guide themselves away from the island, but he could also be suggesting that some sort of divine protection and guidance may have played a part in the men not being present. This call for the involvement of or help from a higher force is the first of many from Sebastian, as he and Nicusa are accused further of making false claims, participating in the absence of the men, and finally acting unlike Christian gentleman. we know not.
Was not the captain
A fellow of a fiery yet bravebrave: fine, worthy nature,
A middle stature, and of brown complexion?
He was, sir.
'Twas Albert
And my poor wretched sister.
'Twas he, certain.
I ha' been at sea with him, many times at sea.
Come, show us these men,
Show us presently, and do not dally with us.
We left 'em here—what should we say, sir?
Here, in this place.
The earth cannot swallow 'em.
They have no wings; they cannot fly, sure.
You told us too
Of heaps of treasure and of sums concealed
That set their hearts afire. We see no such thing,
No such sign. What can ye say to purge purge: clear from accusation or suspicion; also, to vomit ye?
What have ye done with these men?
We, sir?
You, sir.
For certain I believe ye saw such people.
By all that's good,
By all that's pure and honest,
By all that's holy—
I dare not credit credit: give credence to, believe ye.
Ye have so abused abused: misguided my hope that now I hate ye.
Let's put 'em in their ragged clothes again, captain,
For certain they are knaves knaves: persons of common or low status and rank with connotations of dishonesty and cunningness. Let's e'en deliver 'em
To their old fruitful farm old fruitful farm: ironic name for the desolate island, here, let 'em walk the island.
If ye do so we shall curse your mercies.
Rather, put us to sea again—
Not so.
Yes, this I'll do, because ye say ye are Christians,
Though I hardly credit credit: give credence to, believe it: bring in the boat,
And all aboard again but these two wretches.
Yet leave 'em four days' meat; if in that time
(For I will search all nooks of this strange island)
I can discover any tracttract: path travelled by person or animal of these men,
Alive or dead, I'll bear ye off and honor ye.
If not, ye have found your graves. So, farewell.
That goodness dwells above, and knows us innocent,
Comfort our lives, and at his pleasure quitquit: leave us.
Come, cousin, come. Old time will end our story,
But no time (if we end well) ends our glory.

div.stage: Enter Rosella, Clarinda, Crocale, Hippolita, and Juletta.

lg.l: Use 'em with all the austerity austerity: severity that may be;
They are our slaves. Turn all those pities,
Those tender reluctations reluctations: reluctances, aversions to cruelty that should become your sex,
To stern anger, and when ye look upon 'em,
Look with those eyes that wept those bitter sorrows,
Those cruelties ye suffered by their rapines rapines: acts of seizure by force.
Some five days hence, that blessèd hour comes,
Most happy to me, that knit this hand to my dear husband's
And both our hearts in mutual bands that blessed hour ... mutual bands: Rosella refers to the coming anniversary of her and Sebastian's wedding.
That hour, ladies—
What of that hour?
Why, on that hour, daughter,
And in the height of all our celebrations,
Our dear remembrances of that dear man
And those that suffered with him, our fair kinsmen,
Their lives shall fall a sacrifice to vengeance,
Their lives that ruined his. 'Tis a full full: i.e. most fully felt or executed justice.
I will look glorious in their bloods,
And the most noble noble: splendid, magnificent spirit of Sebastian

That perished by the pride of these French pirates French pirates: Fletcher and Massinger give us a play that can easily be read as a commentary on the greed driving European colonization. Rosella's criticism of the French stems from her view of their actions as an attempt to control their commonwealth by robbing valuable things from them. As Rita Banerjee notes, "The critique of piracy in The Sea Voyage centers especially on the inordinate desire for gold and treasure" (294). At the start of the scene, Rosella echoes Tibalt's sentiment from the beginning of the play when he tells the other men to resist obsession with riches to preserve their lives. Because she holds the men responsible for stealing her husband's treasure, Rosella intends to kill them as revenge, thus validating Tibalt's prior warning and reinforcing the critique present throughout the play that riches mean nothing in the face of death; a focus on lust for gold and treasure in the play helps point out that the equating of material goods to personal worth and identity is dangerous and destructive. Of course, in the play's backstory, the Portuguese women (and men) were, themselves, colonists at the time they were driven from their "plantation" by the French. With no mention of the native peoples who were presumably pillaged and displaced by their colonial project, the play elides the violence characteristic of European colonial settlement and figures the Portuguese squarely as victims.
Shall smile in heaven and bless the hand that killed 'em.
Look strictly all unto your prisoners,
For he that makes a 'scape beyond my vengeance,
Or entertains a hope by your fair usagefair usage: just treatment—
Take heed, I say—she that deceives my trust,
Again, take heed: her life—and that's but light neither—
Her life in all tortures my spirit can put on.
We shall be careful.
Do so.
You are angry, mother, and ye are old, too,
Forgetting what men are. But we shall tempertemper: pacify ye.
How fare your prisoners, ladies? In what forms
Do they appear in their afflictions?
Mine fare but poorly,
For so I am commanded; 'tis none of their fault.
Of what sort are they?
They say they are gentlemen,

But they show mongrels they show mongrels: i.e. they appear as dogs or persons of mixed or uncertain descent. The word "mongrel" is chiefly used in a derogatory manner, meaning that this mixed breeding is indicative of a lower form of life. This usage implies the importance of purity of nationality or race and points to an underlying conflict between the French and Portuguese throughout the play. It is also important to note that Juletta calls the Frenchmen "gentlemen," but immediately rescinds that judgement when discussing their behavior. This juxtaposition of superficial appearance with demonstrated behavior also denotes a key conflict throughout the play..
How do they suffer?
Faith, like boys.
They are fearful in all fortunes. When I smile,
They kneel and beg to have that face continue
And, like poor slaves, adore the ground I go on.
When I frown, they hang their most dejected heads
Like fearful sheephounds. Show 'em a crust of bread,
They'll saint me presently, and skip like apes
For a sup sup: sip of wine. I'll whip 'em like hackneys hackneys: horses used for general-purpose riding,

Saddle 'em, ride 'em, do what I will with 'em Saddle 'em ... with 'em: Juletta's speech here highlights a key contention throughout the play: the control of physical sustenance and that of reproductive success, both of which sustain life. Juletta is responsible for looking after her group of men: she is the one giving food to them, as well as presumably exercising sexual dominance over them, as suggested by her phrasing here. The way in which hunger, thirst, and sexual desire are regulated contrasts norms that denied women of the time a good deal of agency; the women in this play, however, are the ones in charge of all physical and sexual sustenance. Though this power is given to the Amazons and reflects an agency not typically experienced by women, their drive to reproduce was is still consistent with traditional pressures on women. As Claire Jowitt puts it, "[T]he text draws a distinction between resources needed for immediate survival—food and water—and those necessary for medium and long-term colonization—children to be new generations of settlers" (99). Though the women have a level of dominance as the food source for their prisoners and the survival source for their population, the burden of having such power is always evident. It is a burden which certainly arose within royal families when the queen was required to produce an heir. This would have been known to a seventeenth-century audience living under a monarchy. Both reproductive capacity and possession of property provide authority in the play, yet both also produce a certain level of balance. Possession and freedom are intertwined in the play—possession of riches and land enables possession of other people. The treasure initially belonged to the Amazons, giving them power, which is then supplemented by taking the men as their prisoners. But, eventually the power transfers back to the men when a concord is reached by marriage..
TushTush: contemptuous, impatient exclamation, these are poor things.
Have they names like Christians?
Very fair names—Franville, Lamure, and Morillat—
And brag of great kindreds too. They offer very handsomely,
But that I am a fool and dare not venture.
They are soundsound: physically healthy; also, morally or intellectually healthy, too, i'my conscience,
Or very near upon't.
FieFie: exclamation inciting shame usually said to children, away, fool.
They tell me
If they might be brought before you
They would reveal things of strange consequence.
Their basebase: despicable, craven poor fears.
Ay, that makes me hate 'em too,
For if they were but manly to their sufferancesufferance: endurance of ongoing pain or penalty,
Sure I should strain a point or twostrain a point or two: i.e. be flexible, even against Rosella's orders.
An hour hence I'll take a view of 'em
And hear their business. Are your men thus, too?
Mine? No, gentle madam, mine were not cast
In such basebase: low-born, not noble molds. Afflictions, tortures
Are names and natures of delight to my men.
All sorts of cruelties they meet like pleasures.
I have two: the one they call du-Pont,
Tibalt du-Pont, the other the shipmaster.
Have they not lives and fears?
Lives they have, madam,
But those lives never linked to such companions
As fears or doubts.
Use 'em noblynobly: finely,
And where you find fit subjects for your pities
Let it become ye to be courteous;
My mother will not always be thus rigorousrigorous: harsh, stern.
Mine are sailors, madam,
But they sleep soundly and seldom trouble me, unless it be when
They dream sometimes of fights and tempests.
Then they roar and whistle for cans of wine
And down they fling me, and in that rage
(For they are violent fellows) they play such reaksreaks: playful or capricious tricks.
If they have meat, they thank me.
If none, they heartily desire to be hanged quickly,
And this is all they care.
Look to 'em diligently, and where your pities tells ye
They may deserve, give comfort.
We will.
Come hither, be not frighted.
Think not ye steal this liberty for we give it.
Your tender innocence assures me, virgin,
Ye had no share in those wrongs these men did us.
I find ye are not hardened in such mischiefs.
Your brother was misled, sure,
Foully misled—
(How much I fear these pities!)
Certain he was, so much I pity him.
And for your sake, whose eyes plead for him—
Nay, for his own sake—
Ha!
For I see about him—
Women have subtlesubtle: wise, perceptive eyes and look narrowly,
Or I am much abusedabused: misguided, mistaken—many fair promises;
Nay, beyond those, too, many shadowedshadowed: adopted as a disguise virtues—
I think he is good.
I assure myself he will be,
And out of that assurance take this comfort,
For I perceive your fear hath much dejected ye:
I love your brother.
Madam—
Nay, do not take it for a dreamt-of favor
That comforts in the sleep and, awake, vanishes.
Indeed, I love him.
Do ye, indeed?
You doubt still because ye fear his safety.
Indeed, he is that sweetest man I e'er saw;
I think the best. Ye may hear without blushes
And give me thanks, if ye please, for my courtesy.
Madam, I ever must
(Yet witness, heaven, they are hard pulled from me).
Believe me, madam, so many imperfections I could find
(Forgive me, grace, for lying) and such wants wants: shortages,
('Tis to an honest use) such poverties,
Both in his main proportionmain proportion: physical form, and his mind too.
There are a hundred handsomer (I lie lewdlylewdly: vulgarly).
Your noblenoble: fine, splendid usage, madam, hath so bound me to ye
That I must tell ye—
Come, tell your worst.
He is no husband for ye;
I think ye mean in that fair way I think ... fair way: I think that is your meaning—
Ye have hit it.
(I am sure ye have hit my heart.)
You will find him dangerous, madam,
As fickle as the flying flying: fleeing air; proud, jealous,
Soon glutted in your sweets, and soon forgetful.
I could say more and tell ye I have a brother,
Another brother, that so far excels this,
Both in the ornaments ornaments: qualities, characteristics of man, and making—
If you were not his sister I should doubt ye mainly mainly: strongly,
Doubt ye for his love, ye deal so cunningly.
Do not abuse abuse: misguide me. I have trusted ye with more than life,
With my first love. Be careful with me.
In what use, madam?
In this, lady:
Speak to him for me—you have power upon him—
Tell him I love him, tell him I dote dote: foolishly shower with love on him.
It will become your tongue—
(Become my grave.
Oh fortune! Oh, cursed fortune!)
Tell him his liberty,

And all those with him, all our wealth and jewels all our wealth and jewels: Clarinda's promise of wealth and jewels to Albert in her hopes of wooing him acts as a dowry. In offering it, she also offers salvation as she plans to spare his life, thus enabling a future for life on the island itself through reproduction. She is actually reversing the original cause of enmity between the two groups by giving the stolen treasure back to him while hoping to attain their union, which, though she is unable to do without patriarchal sanction, represents the play's harmonious ending by marriage between groups. As Jowitt notes, "The plot of The Sea Voyage follows the haphazard and hostile interaction between these colonies until, finally, an understanding between the groups is achieved which enables them to pool resources"(Jowitt, 99).-
Good sister, for I'll call ye so—
I shall, lady
(Even die, I hope).
Here's meat and wine—pray, take it—
And there he lies. Give him what liberty you please—
But still concealed—what pleasure you shall please, sister—

He shall ne'er wantwant: lack again Here's meat ... want again: Although Aminta and Clarinda have come from different groups, they work together to sustain Albert. Clarinda's nutritional provision for Albert is supplemented by Aminta's romantic/sexual provision for him, which in turn makes possible the ensuing sequence of events that ends the play in a way that ensures the survival of all involved. The idea of union between two factions is again emphasized, but beyond that it juxtaposes the threat to survival posed by division and distinction between groups, neither of which have all the necessary means of survival without the other. As Jowitt points out, it is only "between the separate factions [that] there are enough resources to ensure a sustainable lifestyle" (99). —nay, see and you'll take it—
Why do you study thus?
To avoid mischiefs, if they should happen.
Go and be happy for me.
Oh, blind Fortune;
Yet happy thus far, I shall live to see him.
In what strange desolation lives he here now?

Sure this curtain will reveal Sure this curtain will reveal: Based on the structure of many early modern playhouses, including the second Globe where this play was performed in 1622, it is likely the "curtain" to which Aminta refers is the arras across a "discovery space" in the middle of the tiring house wall which would have hidden Albert from view. As Syme notes, "Even if there was no central stage door, there would have been an area between the two entrances that lay concealed behind an arras or curtain that could be drawn to reveal preset tableaux" (115).—
Who's that? Ha!
Some gentle hand, I hope, to bring me comfort,
Or if it be my death, 'tis sweetly shadowedshadowed: disguised.
Have ye forgot me, sir?
My Aminta?
She, sir,
That walks here up and down an empty shadow,
One that for some few hours
But wanders here carrying her own sad coffin,
Seeking some desert place to lodge her griefs in.
Sweet sorrow, welcome. Welcome, noble grief.
How got you this fair liberty to see me,
For sorrows in your shape are strangers to me?
I come to counsel ye.
Ye are still more welcome,
For good friends in afflictions give good counsels.
Pray then, proceed.
Pray, eat first, ye show faint.
Here's wine to refresh ye too.
I thank ye, dear. Albert eats and drinks.
Drink again.
Here's to our loves—
How, turn and weep!
Pray, pledgepledge: drink or toast to it, this happiness we have left.
Our hearts are free—not pledge pledge: drink or toast to it? Why,
And though beneath the axe beneath the axe: threatened by death this health this health: i.e. Albert's drink were holy,
Why do ye weep thus?
I come to woo ye.
To woo me, sweet? I am wooed and won already.
You know I am yours. This prettypretty: cunning, crafty way becomes ye—
But you would deceive my sorrows, that's your intent.
I would I could; I should not weep, but smile.
Do ye like your meat and wine?
Like it?
Do you like your liberty?
All these I well may like.
Then pray, like her that sent 'em.
Do ye like wealth, and most unequalled beauty?
Peace, indeed you'll make me angry.
Would I were dead that ask it,
Then ye might freely like, and I forgive ye.
What like? And who? Add not more misery
To a man that's fruitful in afflictions.
Who is't you would have me like?
Who sent these comforts?
I must tell—
Be bold—
But be you temperate.
If you be bold, I die. The young fair virgin
(Sorrow hath made me old)—oh, harkenharken: listen well,
And wisely hark—the governess' daughter,
That star that strikes this island full of wonder,
That blooming sweetness—
What of her?
She sent it, and with it—
It must be out—she dotesdotes: foolishly showers with love on ye,
And must enjoy ye, else no joy must find ye.
And have you the patiencepatience: emotional endurance; also, permission to deliver this?
A sister may say much, and modestly.
A sister?
Yes, that name undid ye,
Undid us both. Had ye named wifeHad ye named wife: i.e. Had ye named me as your wife, she had feared ye
And feared the sin she followed, she had shunned, yea,
Her virgin modesty had not touched at ye.
But thinking you were free hath kindled a fire
I fear will hardly be extinguished.
Indeed, I played the fool—
Oh, my best sir, take heed,
Take heed of lies! Truth, though it trouble some minds,
Some wicked minds that are both dark and dangerous,
Yet it preserves itself, comes off pure, innocent,
And like the sun, though never so eclipsed,
Must breakbreak: burst forth in glory. Oh, sir, lie no more.
Ye have read me a fair lecture
And put a spell upon my tongue for feigningfeigning: lying.
But how will you counsel now?
Ye must study to forget me.
How?
Be patient,
Be wise and patient, it concerns ye highly:
Can ye lay bylay by: lay aside your loves? But why should I doubt it?
Ye are a man, and men may shift affections;
'Tis held no sin. To come to the point,
Ye must lose me, many and mighty reasons—
Hear me, Aminta:
Have you a man that loves you too, that feeds ye,
The sends ye liberty? Has this great governess
A noblenoble: fine, splendid son, too, young and apt to catch ye?
Am I, because I am in bonds and miserable,
My health decayed, my youth and strength half-blasted,
My fortune, like my waning self, for this despiseddespised: scorned, disdained?
Am I for this forsaken? A new love chosen
And my affections, like my fortunes, wanderers?
Take heed of lying, you that chidchid: scolded me for it
And showed how deep a sin it was, and dangerous;
Take heed yourself: you swore you loved me dearly.
No few, nor little oaths you swore, Aminta;
Those sealed with no small faith, I then assured myself.
Oh, seek no new ways to cozencozen: deceive or dupe truth!
I do not.
By love itself, I love thee,
And ever must, nor can all deaths dissolve it.
Why do you urge me thus, then?
For your safety,
To preserve your life.
My life, I do confess, is hers. She gives it
And let her take it back; I yield it.
My love's entirely thine. None shall touch at it.
None, my Aminta, none.
Ye have made me happy,
And now I know ye are mine. Fortune Fortune: goddess of luck, I scornscorn: defy thee.
Go to your rest and I'll sit by ye.
While I have time I'll be your mate and comfort ye,
For only I am trusted. You shall wantwant: lack nothing,
Not a liberty that I can steal ye.
May we not celebrate our loves, Aminta? Albert tries to kiss Aminta
And where our wishes cannot meet—
You are wantonwanton: undisciplined, unjust, sexually forward,
But with cold kisses I'll allay allay: alleviate, bring down that fever.Aminta kisses Albert
Look for no more, and that in private, too.
Believe me, I shall blush, else.
But let's consider, we are both lost, else.
Let's in, and prevent fate.

div.stage: Enter Crocale, Juletta, Tibalt, and Master.

lg.l: You do well to air us, ladies; we shall be musty, else.
What are your wise wills now?
You are very crankcrank: high in spirits still—
As crankcrank: high in spirits as a holy friar fed with hailstones.
But do ye bring us out to baitbait: harass like bulls?
Or are you weary of the charge charge: responsibility; also, burden ye are at?
Turn us abroad again; let's jog, ladies.
We are gross gross: large-bodied; also, common or inferior and coarse coarse: vulgar, unfit for your sweet pleasures.
Knock off our shoes, and turn's to grass turn's to grass: put us out to pasture; possibly also kill us.
You are determined
Still to be stubborn, then; it well becomes ye.
An humor humor: mood, lady, that contents a prisoner.
A sullen fit sometimes serves for a second course.
Ye may as well be kind
And gain our favors, gain meat and drink,
And lodging to rest your bones—
My bones have bore me thus long
And had their share of pains and recreations.
If they sail now, they are no fair companions.
Are ye thus harsh to all our sex?
We cannot be merry without a fiddler.
Pray, strike up your tabors tabors: drums, ladies.
The fools despise despise: scorn, disdain us.
We know ye are very hungry now.
Yes, 'tis very wholesome wholesome: beneficial, ladies,
For we that have gross gross: large-bodied; also, common or inferior bodies must be careful.
Have ye no piercing air to stir our stomachs?
We are beholding beholding: obligated, indebted to ye for our ordinary ordinary: daily meal; also, the tavern in which such meals are served.
Why, slaves, 'tis in our power to hang ye.
Very likely.
'Tis in our powers then to be hanged, and scornscorn: defy ye.
Hanging's as sweet to us as dreaming to you.
Come, be more courteous.
Do, and then ye shall be pleased and have all necessaries.
Give me some ratsbaneratsbane: rat poison then.
And why ratsbaneratsbane: rat poison, monsieur?
We live like vermin here, and eat up your cheese,
Your moldy cheese that none but rats would bite at.
Therefore 'tis just that ratsbaneratsbane: rat poison should reward us.
We are unprofitable, and our ploughs are broken.
There is no hope of harvest this year, ladies.
Ye shall have all contentcontent: satisfaction—
Ay, and we'll serve your uses.
I had rather serve hogs, there's more delight in't.
Your greedy appetites are never satisfied.
Just like hungry camels, sleeping or waking
You chew the cud still.
By this hand, we'll starve ye.
'Tis a noble noble: fine, splendid courtesy.
I had as lief had as lief: would be glad ye should famish me as founder founder: physically punish me.
To be jadedjaded: worn out by strenuous work to death is only fit for a hackney hackney: horse used for general-purpose riding.
Here be certain tarts of tar about me To Aminta

And parcels of potargo parcels of potargo: Bottarga (potargo) are dried and salted sacs of fish eggs, usually made from mullet or tuna. It is difficult and time-consuming to make because it involves salt baths, massaging, and weeks of aging. The Master's joke here is doubly felt because the prisoners have no access to food at all, let alone a type of food that was difficult to make and considered a luxury. Bottarga is enjoyed more widely today, but it is still considered a delicacy (Squadrilli). in my jerkin jerkin: men's jacket,
As long as these last—
Which will not last ever—
Then we'll eat one another like good fellows,
A shoulder of his for a haunch of mine.
'Tis excellent—
'Twill be as we'll dressdress: prepare it, ladies.
Why sure ye are not men.
Ye had best come search us.
A seaman is seldom without a salt eel salt eel: rope made of dried eel skin used for flogging, here used as a phallic image—
I am bad enough,
And in my nature a notorious wencher wencher: one who frequently seeks out the company of women, with implications of promiscuity,
And yet ye make me blush at your immodesty.
Tell me, good Master, didst ever see such things?
I could like 'em, though they were lewdly lewdly: ignorantly, foolishly given,
If they could say no. But fie fie: exclamation inciting shame, usually said to children on 'em,

They gape like oysters They gape like oysters: This line has sexual connotations because in this era oysters were viewed as a venereal symbol and considered an aphrodisiac. More specifically, oysters were associated with vulvas. Beyond that, Gordon Williams notes that during the period a woman could be "defined through her sexual part" (982). The Master is essentially sexualizing the women and reducing them to their anatomy. "Gape" is additionally suggestive in this context as it could imply the Master and Tibalt resent the women's power over their own sexuality: the women are imagined to be opening their own sexual anatomy and thus exerting control of their sexual fates..
Well, ye may hang or starve us,
But your commanding impudence shall never fearfear: in this case, frighten us.
Had ye by blushing signs—soft cunnings—crept into us
And showed us your necessities, we had met your purposes,

Supplied your wants wants: shortages. We are no saints, ladies. Had ye ... ladies: Throughout this scene, identifying innuendo is imperative to understanding the exchange among the characters. In response to Crocale, who says Tibalt and the Master are "not men," the Master assures her she will find a "salt eel" (a phallic symbol) if she should "search" them. This image is soon met by an observation that the women "gape like oysters." As oysters were understood to represent the vagina, their gaping suggests the sexual desire of the women themselves. The phrase "crept into us" makes the sexual connotations of his speech unmistakable, allowing the "necessities" and "wants" of the women to equivocate with both sexual desire and the desire of obedience from the men. Sex is then tied to power for the women as it is to food for the men.
I love a good wench as I love my life,
And with my life I will maintain my love,

But such a sordid impudence I'll spit at such a sordid impudence I'll spit at: Much of Tibalt and the Master's frustration with their imprisonment seems to be that they regard the women's behavior as "unwomanly." Tibalt is willing to accept a painful death, but he refuses to accept the commanding behavior and attitude of the women in charge of him, and states that he would be willing to accept their position if they acted more ladylike and milder. Tibalt and the Master seem to have strong perceptions of how women should act, and these Amazon women do not adhere to their expectations, suggesting it is the reversal of gender roles that is key to the conflict in this moment..
Let's to our dens again. Come, noble noble: fine, good Master.
You know our minds, ladies.
This is the faith in which we'll die.
I do admire 'em.
They are noble noble: fine, splendid fellows,
And they shall not want want: lack for this.
But see, Clarinda comes.
Farewell, I'll to my charge charge: responsibility; also, burden.
Bring out those prisoners now
And let me see 'em and hear their business.
I will, madam.
I hope she hath prevailed prevailed: succeeded in persuading upon her brother.
She has a sweet tongue has a sweet tongue: is persuasive, is agreeable and can describe the happiness
My love is ready to fling on him.
And sure, he must be glad and, certain, wonder
And bless the hour that brought him to this island.
I long to hear the full full: i.e. a most fully felt or accumulated joy that he labors with.

div.stage: Enter Juletta, Morillat, Franville, and Lamure. They kneel.

lg.l: Bless thy divine beauty—
Mirror of sweetness—
Ever springing brightness—
Nay, stand up, gentlemen, and leave your flatteries. They rise.
She calls us gentlemen. Sure, we shall have some meat now.
I am a mortal creature,
Worship heaven, and give these attributes
To their divinities. Methinks ye look but thin.
Oh we are starved, immortal beauty—
We are all poor starved knaves knaves: persons of common or low status and rank with connotations of dishonesty and cunningness—
Neither liberty nor meat, lady.
We were handsome men, and gentlemen, and sweet men,
And were once gracious gracious: favorable in appearance in the eyes of beauties,
But now we look like rogues,
Like poor starved rogues.
What would ye do if ye were to die now?
Alas, we were prepared. If you will hang us,
Let's have a good meal or two to die with,
To put's in heartTo put's in heart: To fortify our courage—
Or if you'll drown us,
Let's be drunk first, that we may die merrily
And bless the founders founders: i.e. those who founder (or, drown) us—
Ye shall not die so hastily.
What dare ye do to deserve my favor?
Put us to any service—
Any bondage,
Let's but live—
We'll get a world of children,

For we know ye are heinously provided that way For we know ... that way: The French gentlemen, who boarded their ship as noblemen, describe themselves as almost nothing —rogues and knaves— and plead with Clarinda to put them in any service to live, even if it's simply to help procreate. This exchange, and also the lines later when Morillat tells Clarinda to beat them if they offend them(which is an open admittance of their subservient positions at this time), speak to gender roles and the challenge that this play introduces to gender stereotypes. These men are now shipwrecked on an island where women are in charge and to which the men have brought almost no value; their own value, now, is procreative. In an era where men traditionally provide for the household but women ultimately create life, the power dynamic has been turned upside down, with both parties still depending on the other, but for reversed services.;
And ye shall beat us when we offend ye,

Beat us abundantly, and take our meat from us take our meat from us: In many instances in this play, "meat" also references a man's sexual desire for a woman's body. In The Sexual Politics of Meat, Carol Adams discusses the ways that references to meat-eating is directly linked to masculine aspects of our own modern culture (1). The Sea Voyage reflects this same dynamic throughout. For example, Morillat suggests that Albert captured Aminta for his own "appetite." Throughout it is only the men who beg for meat and seem to have this kind of "appetite." This emphasis on meat throughout, as opposed to other food sources, suggests that the The Sea Voyage is exploring the complicated ways in which meat and women's bodies are equated during the early modern period..
These are weak abject abject: lowly, desperate, obsequious things that show ye poor ones.
What's the great service ye so oft have threatened
If ye might see me, and win my favor?
That business of discovery—
Oh, I'll tell ye, lady—
And so will I—
And I!
Pray, let me speak first.
Good, no confusion.
We are before a lady that knows manners,
And by the next, meat I shall eat, 'tis certain.
This little gentlewoman that was taken with us—
Your captain's sister? She, you mean?
Ay, ay, she's the business that we would openopen: reveal to ye.
You are cozenedcozened: deceived or duped in her—
How, what is't you would openopen: reveal?
She is no sister—
Good sirs, how quick you are.
She is no sister, madam.
She is his—
Peace, I say—
What is she?
Faith, sweet lady,
She is, as a man would say, his.
What?
His mistress—
Or, as some new translators read, his—
Oh me!
And why he should deludedelude: deceive you thus,
Unless he meant some villainy? These ten weeks
He has had her at sea for his own proper appetite—
His cabinmate, I'll assure ye—
No sister, say ye?
No more than I am brother to your beauty.
I know not why he should jugglejuggle: trick so as to deceive thus—
Do not lie to me.
If ye find me lie, lady, hang me empty.
How am I fooled!
Away with 'em, Juletta, and feed 'em,
But hark ye, with such food as they have given me:
New misery!
Nor meat, nor thanks for all this!
Make 'em more wretched—
Oh, I could burst! Curse and kill now,
Kill anything I meet! Juletta, follow me,
And call the rest along.
We follow, madam.
I must be gone now, else she may suspect me.
How shall I answer her?
Tell her directly.
That were too sudden, too improvidentimprovident: rash, lacking foresight.
Fires of this nature must be put out cunningly;
They'll wastewaste: destroy all come near 'em, else.
Farewell once more.
Farewell,
And keep my love entire—
Nay, kiss me once again, methinks we should not part.
Oh, be wise, sir.
Nay, one kiss more.
Indeed, you're wantonwanton: undisciplined, lustful.
We may be taken, too—

div.stage: Enter Clarinda, Juletta, Crocale, and Hippolita.

lg.l: Out, thou base base: low-born; also, morally low woman!
By heaven, I'll shoot 'em both!
Nay, stay stay: stop, halt, brave brave: fine, worthy lady, hold.
A sudden death cuts of a nobler nobler: more powerful, finer vengeance.
Am I made bawd bawd: enabler or encourager of sexual or evil acts to your lascivious meetings?
Are ye grown so wise in sin?
Shut up that villain. And sirrah sirrah: contemptuous address used to men and boys,
Now expect my utmost anger:
Let him there starve—
I mock at your mischiefs.
Tie that false false: deceitful witch unto that tree.
There, let the savage beasts
Gnaw of her sweetness, and snakes
Embrace her beauties. Tie her, and watch
That none relieve her.

sp.speaker: Hippolita
sp.stage: Hippolita tying Aminta to a tree.

lg.l: We could wish ye better fortune, lady,
But dare not help ye.
Be your own friends, I thank ye.
Now only my last audit audit: solemn rendering of accounts, sometimes used to refer to what happens on Judgment Day, and my greatest:
Oh, heaven, be kind unto me,
And if it be thy will, preserve—
Who is this?
Sure, 'tis a woman—I have trod this place
And found much footingfound much footing: discovered many human tracks; now I know 'tis peopled—
Ha, let me see! 'Tis her face.
Oh, heaven ! Turn this way, maid.
Oh, Raymond! Oh, brother!
Her tongue too; 'tis my sister. What rude hand—
Nay, kiss me first—Oh, joy!
FlyFly: Flee, flyfly: flee, dear brother,
You are lost, else!
A man, a man, a new man!
What are these?
An enemy, an enemy!
Dispatch him,
Take him off, shoot him straight!
I dare not use my sword, ladies,
Against such comely foes.
Oh, brother, brother!
Away with 'em, and in dark prisons bind 'em.
One word repliedOne word replied: If you speak at all, ye die, both.
Now, brave brave: fine, worthy mother, follow thy noble noble: fine, magnificent anger
And I'll help thee.
